title: How to Fit an Electric Shower

steps.headline: Pick a location for your electric shower that is near the main cold water supply and close to a spot where you can install an independent circuit.
Consult an electrician for advice on the size and type of independent circuit to install for your shower to ensure that you have adequate electricity.
steps.description: You will likely have to include a consumer unit with your circuit.

steps.headline: Consult a plumber to ensure that your building's plumbing system will be able to accommodate an electric shower.
Install the independent circuit near the location of the electric shower along with any necessary consumer units or earth cables.
Wire the independent circuit to an isolating switch, which should be located above the shower.
steps.description: This will allow the shower to turn off when not working.

steps.headline: Attach the electric cable from the isolating switch to the back of the electric shower power unit and wire accordingly.
steps.description: Inspect and test the electrical installation, in compliance with local electrical standards, regulations and legislation. This is to ensure that it is safe to use and will not kill persons using it, in the event of a fault.

steps.headline: Secure a pipe from the cold water main supply to the spot where the shower unit will be mounted.
Attach a non-return valve or stop tap to the pipe to isolate the shower's water supply from the rest of the building.
Attach the pipe to the shower unit using a compression fitting.
Mount the shower unit and the shower head to the wall.
Turn on the water supply and the independent circuit.
Check to see that the electric shower is heating the water quickly and efficiently.
